message: On an AppEngine app I made, I remember using memcache quite a bit. Should I use that or is there something similar on ep.io's machines?
I think you are supposed to use Redis as a cache instead. (I think there's an adaptor for that for Django.)
You can use http://code.google.com/p/django-redis-cache/
Yep, we don't offer memcached as it's not secure
We might offer it in future, with the caveat that anyone else will be able to read and write to it
Gotcha'. Does caching in redis significantly reduce database usage? Does the added cost of using redis justify it?
@dsr Redis is very flexible; you can use it as a simple key-value cache, like memcached, which many people do
However, most production deployments I know of use it as a glorified cache
@dsr Redis performs very similarly to memcached, and beats it in some benchmarks
most notably, the persistance is not crash-proof - it will lose the last X seconds of data if it dies, unlike PostgreSQL, which writes transactions to disk as they come in
It takes a special service to build an app entirely on it - early ep.io was, and we've since moved nearly everything into PostgreSQL
So speed and flexibility are the selling points.
Indeed, redis is incredibly quick
So you can treat it the same. As for cost, until we launch the new pricing scheme, I couldn't say, but it'll speed up page loads nonetheless
So is it common to use both the Postgres database and Redis together? Or just one or the other?
or, you can use it for storing more structured data (it can do sets of values, server-side union and intersection, pub/sub messaging, and more)
Heh, no problem - it is persistent, and saves to disk, but that can be turned off
Is it persistent? (I'm new to more than SQL databases, obviously.)
but it can be done.
So recommended usage is to augment a PostgresSQL database?
@dsr Yep, especially if you're new to using Redis and don't have a good idea of its strengths and weaknesses yet
